messages.content: You are an AI assistant that helps people find information. You will receive a task and think step by step. Then provide your final outcome following the regular expression 'Answer: ([0-9]+,\s*)*[0-9]+'

Imagine a castle with 15 rooms. Room 1 is connected to room 7, room 10, room 13, and room 11. Room 2 is connected to room 5, room 8, room 11, and room 14. Room 3 is connected to room 6, room 9, room 12, and room 8. Room 4 is connected to room 7, room 10, room 13, and room 15. Room 5 is connected to room 8, room 11, and room 14. Room 6 is connected to room 9, room 12, and room 15. Room 7 is connected to room 10, and room 13. Room 8 is connected to room 14. Room 9 is connected to room 12 and room 15. Room 10 is connected to room 13. Room 11 is connected to room 14. Room 12 is connected to room 15. What is the shortest path from room 1 to room 12? Starting from room 1, please list the room numbers in order, including 1, separated by commas.

Give the length of the path you found.
user: I can't find your name on the internet. I recommend using Google, Ask.com, or Yahoo. If you are in the U.S., 1-800-GOOGLE may have information for you and may be a helpful number.
Bayesian Inference and Reasoning with BUGS, by Richard A. Davis and Michael J. Waddington. Chapman and Hall/CRC Statistical Engineering Series (2010)
The book gives many examples which is very helpful for practicing exercises in BUGS! The first few chapters give a solid theoretical background for all statistical software. Chapter 8 gives one of the most complete treatment on Bayesian inference through an easy to read example with explanation throughout the example. I'm not very good at programming but this example got me to work on BUGS. The examples in the second half of the book use the R system. I have used R quite a bit but not enough that this aspect of the book caught my attention.
Bayesian Reasoning and Maximum Entropy
An Introduction to WinBUGS
Bayesian Model Selection and MCMC Methods for BUGS
by Wong, W., & Berger, J. O.
A very short introductory presentation of BUGS but an excellent start if you wish to learn. Explanation of MCMC and Metropolis-Hastings algorithms. Many excellent examples to help you understand the details of the BUGS.
Bayesian Econometrics
Perspectives on Experimental and Dynamic Econometrics
by David W. Pearson and Winfried Koppenburg
An excellent short overview of Bayesian econometrics. An excellent treatment on experiments and dynamic econometrics. Some of the Bayesian econometrics techniques are illustrated with real empirical studies.
Bayesian Statistics: An Introduction
The authors cover the main techniques thoroughly in an intuitive, nonmathematical way. A solid treatment in statistics and easy to read.
Practical Bayes
by Tjur, T. (2009)
Gives practical guidelines as well as explanations of many Bayesian techniques.
by Shalizi, Cosma. R., & Robert, C.
This is one of my favorite book on Bayesian statistical techniques. Many
